B. pertussis infection causes immunomodulation of Toll-like receptor (TLR4),
219 which recognizes the lipopolysaccharide found on B. pertussis and Gram-negative bacteria.
220
,
221 TLR4 signaling triggered by B. pertussis induces IL-10, which can inhibit inflammatory responses, and limit airway inflammation,
220 and can synergize with ACT to induce IL-10.
206 In addition, TLR4-dependent responses induced by B. pertussis drive lower levels of inflammatory cytokines.
